hackathon-description-text: Do you love Planet Earth and want to preserve it for future generations? Come and be part of the solution at Stanford inaugural Stanford Big Earth Data Hackathon.
hackathon-requirements: Project descriptions and hacks must be posted to devpost prior to 8am on Sunday, April 15 to be considered for prizes. (Hacking continues until 9am, but we need an initial project description in order to assign you a spot at the Project Expo and for Judging purposes)
hackathon-rules:
All participants must meet eligibility requirements.
All participants must also abide by a 
 which is outlined below:

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Each member of the team with the best planetary solution will receive a brand new electric scooter.
Each member of the 2nd place team will receive an Xbox One S.
Echo Spot for each member of the 3rd place team.
Each member of the  team who best uses AWS credits in their project will each receive an Echo Dot
An Echo Dot will be awarded to each member of the team who has the best seismic noise detection.
Each member of the team who makes best use of MATLAB for their project will receive a $40 Amazon gift card.
Each member of the team who makes best use of multiple data sets will receive a $40 Amazon gift card.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Mapbox solution using multiple data sources

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Each member of the team who makes best use of Planet data for their project will receive a $40 Amazon gift card.
Each member of the team who makes best use of Satellogic Data will receive a $40 Amazon gift card. In addition, the winning team can task a satellite to capture an image of whatever they want.
For the best solo (team of 1) project, the winner will receive a Echo Spot.

hackathon-location-address: The Ruth Wattis Mitchell Earth Sciences Building, 397 Panama Mall, Stanford, CA 94305, USA
hackathon-description-header: Come find solutions to planetary problems at the inaugural Stanford Big Earth Data hackathon
hackathon-location-description: Stanford University - Mitchell Earth Sciences Building
